div.head:
Embleme 8. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Take an egge and smite it with a fiery sword.

lg.l: Rest not till you have found that egge soe rare,
Descended from the loftyest bird oth' aire:
With fire and steele (noe otherwise) confound
The slimy white which dos the yolke surround;
Though to the God of fire Mars ayd shall give,
The product will of both the victor live.

div.head: Discourse 8.
div.ab:
Many and severall sorts of birds there are, which as they are indefinite in number, soe
are they unknowne to us by names: Story tells us of a very great bird appearing at a
certaine time of the year in a small Isle of the sea called Ruc, because it can lift
up an Elephant with it into the aire. India and America doe yeild parrotts of va
rious colour, Crows, and the like: but it is not the philosophicall intention to in
quire after the eggs of these birds: The Aegyptians doe yearly infest, and as it
were with a publicke warre denounced prosecute the Eggs of Crocodiles with
weapons of iron; the philosophers doe burne their egge with fire, not to mortify
and destroy it, but that it may receive life and growth; for when a chicken is
from theme produced animated and living, it cannot be sayd to be the corruption
but generation of it: it ceaseth indeed to be an egge by the privation of the ovall
forme, and begins to be an animall with two feet and volatile by the introduction
of a more noble forme: In an egge are the seeds of both male and female
joyned together under one cover or shell: The yolke constitutes the chicken,
and the radicall parts and bowells thereof, the seed of the male being the
former, and internall efficient: The white yeilds matter, or thread and incre
ment to the rudiment as it were to the warp of the chicken: Externall heat
is the first mover, which doth by a certaine circulation of the Elements, toge
ther with instinct and guidance of nature introduce a new forme by
changing one thing into another: for water turnes into aire, aire into fire, and
fire into earth, upon the conjunction of which, a specificke forme being trans
mitted by the starrs, an individuall is made of a certaine kind of bird, namely
of that, whose egge it was, and seed infused in it. Is it indeed sayd to be smitten
with a fiery sword, whilst Vulcan officiating the duty of a midwife gives pas
sage or egresse to the chicken by his axe, as to pallas outout of the braine of Ju
piter: This is that which Basill Valentine affirms, that Mercury was impri
soned by Vulcan at the comand of Mars, and not released, before hee was
wholy putrefyd and dead: but this death is to him the begining of a new life,
as the corruption or death of an egge brings new generation and life to the
chicken, soe an Embryo being freed from that humane vegetable life (which
alone hee enjoyed in his mothers wombe, another more perfect is obtained by
coming into the light of this world, as by nativity: yea allso wee being de
prived of this present life, which wee lead, another most perfect and aeter
nall is at hand: Thus Lully doth in many places call this fiery sword a
sharp spear; because fire doth as a sharp spear or sword perforate bodyes,
and make them porous and pervious, that water can penetrate to dissolve
and reduce them from hardnesse to softnesse and tractability. In the
stomacke of a Cormorant, which is of all birds most voracious, are found
long and round wormes alive, which are to it as the instrument of heat,
they forthwith invading, and as most sharp noodles perforating, (as wee
have sometimes observed) and soe in a very short time consuming
the Eeles and other fish taken by it, with a wonderfull operation of na
ture: as therefore heat pricketh, soe a thing pricking sometimes supplys the
Discourse 8.
place of heat: upon which consideration that, wherewith the philosophers egge
ought to be pieced and smitten, may not undeservedly be called a fiery sword:
but the philosophers had rather have it understood of a temperate heat, where
by the egge is kept warme, as Morfolens in Turba declares, saying, wise men
ought to burne away moisture first with a slow fire, as is shewed to us by an
example in the generation of a chicken, and where the fire is augmented,
the vessell must be stopd on all sides, that the body of the brasse, and the
fugitive spirit thereof may not exhale. But what birds was the egge? Mos
cus in the same plate; now I say, sayth hee, that noe instruments are
made, except of our white, starry, splendid powder, and of the white
stone, of which powder are made fitt instruments for the egge; yet they
have not names the egge, nor what birds the egge was
